div.p:
Narrator:
The cost of high-risk choices can be devastating to those who have made them. But there are others who suffer unimaginable loss through no choice of their own.

Benton:
I first met Jon-Erik in 1991, I believe it was. If I'm not mistaken Jon-Erik was probably 7 or 8 years old at that time. He was a typical little boy, he loved to get into things and loved to ask a million questions, but I just remember Jon-Erik just being a bright bubbly young child with a good future ahead of him.

Jon-Erik:
While I was in my senior year of high school, I had a black Firebird. Oh boy, it was a chick magnet. I used to ride around in that thing with my girlfriend and she was the one driving her vehicle that I was in when we were hit head-on by a drunk driver who was in the wrong lane.

Dad:
The deputy sheriff came to my door around 11, he was on a cell phone, wanted to know if I was Jon-Erik's father. I said yes I am, he said Jon-Erik's been in a wreck, and they're going to helicopter him to Greenville, to Greenville Memorial Hospital. And wanted me to get ready and go there.

Narrator:
Jon-Erik sustained a skull fracture and traumatic brain injury from the wreck. It put him in the hospital for 10 months, 7 of them in a coma.

Jon-Erik:
Just imagine, yourself lying in a hospital bed with tubes inside of your stomach to feed you and an air pipe running to your throat because you can't breathe through your injured mouth and nose. Imagine laying there, imagine laying there for over 7 months, 7 months.

Benton:
It really broke my heart, it was hard. Twenty seconds can take you from a promising future to a possibility of not even being here.

Narrator:
The driver of the other car was killed in the crash.

Dad:
He had a long history of driving offenses, driving under the influence, and he ended up at one of the bars at 5 in the afternoon until around ten o'clock that night, which caused him to be highly impaired, and to hit my car my son was riding in head-on.

Narrator:
While still in a coma, Jon-Erik was moved to a rehabilitation hospital, where he went through intense physical therapy. One of the lifelong effects of his injuries is ataxia, a loss of balance and full control of his limbs.

Jon-Erik:
I still cannot walk independently besides I mean, the walker, I use a walker.

Narrator:
Jon-Erik also suffers from short-term memory loss.

Jon-Erik:
You tell me your name and a few seconds later I'll forget who you are. It's just destroyed my uh, my future for now.

Narrator:
Jon-Erik's mother passed away when he was a child, so Haskell has been his primary caretaker since the crash.

Dad:
Someone has to maintain his daily medicine, medication, prepare his food for him in most cases. He probably will never be able to live on his own ever again.

Narrator:
Before the crash, Jon-Erik was living the life of a normal teenager. He was an athlete, an exceptional student, and awarded a scholarship at the University of South Carolina. The crash happened nine days before he was to start school.

Dad:
And he'd love to go back to school, to college, and probably never be able to go.

Jon-Erik:
I probably to tell the truth I wouldn't even be able to remember my teacher's name. I mean, that's how bad this has affected me, has affected my whole life and it's affected my whole family.

Dad:
The hardest thing I had to do was cancel his classes at the school because I wanted him to get more education than I had, I was not able to go to college, and I didn't go to college, and he was, made the grades in school to go.

Narrator:
There were over a million dollars in hospital bills, and the drunk driver had no liability insurance. But because Jon-Erik was 18 at the time, he was deemed responsible for the debt.

Dad:
Otherwise I would've had to declare bankruptcy, because I would've been responsible for the bills.

Jon-Erik:
My father had to miss work while coming to visit me in my hospital. I mean he had to leave and put a sign on the door saying you know, be back later, going to go visit my son dying in the hospital.

Narrator:
While at the rehab hospital, Jon-Erik met Roland Hill, a fellow patient who would become a close friend.

Roland:
I really had a heart for Jon-Erik when I saw, man, how far can he get? There's no telling what he could have been. He'd run track, he was smart enough to graduate early. He was aspiring to become a psychiatrist. He had a potential of so much. But that wreck stopped it.

Benton:
This world is definitely at a loss, because I just believe he was going to do things that would change people's lives.

Roland:
One thing that doesn't show a lot, Jon-Erik's had to battle depression.

Jon-Erik:
I don't have a girlfriend because, instead of, you know, I was lying in a coma, now I haven't really seen her in, it's been a long time. She don't come around no more, like the song says, "She don't come around..." It's been pretty hard, pretty rough for me.

Dad:
I lost the possibility probably of grandkids in the future. But he lost the possibility of having kids himself, a wife.

Roland:
He and I talk about getting along with girls a lot of times. He seems to be interested in what it's like to be married.

Jon-Erik:
My friend Roland, he says they'll have some new advances in medical research, and they'll have something out that will help my memory. I hope that's true, if not then I don't know what I'm going to do the rest of my life.
